subdivisions.description: Emissions from residential buildings are sourced directly from IEA CO2 emissions from fuel combustion reports.
subdivisions.label: Residential

subdivisions.description: Emissions from commercial buildings are sourced directly from IEA CO2 emissions from fuel combustion reports.
subdivisions.label: Commerce/Public

subdivisions.description: Emissions from industrial facilities are produced from energy consumption in industrial buildings. See supporting documentation for further details on allocation assumptions.
subdivisions.label: Industrial facilities

nodes.description: F-gases are potent, man-made GHG emissions that can be split into four types: Hydrofuorocarbons (HFCs), Perfluorocarbons (PFCs), Sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) and Nitrogen trifluoride (NF3). F-gas emissions can be thousands of times worse for climate change than CO2 emissions (see www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch2s2-10-2.html)
nodes.title: F-gas

subdivisions.description: F-gases are potent, man-made GHG emissions that can be split into four types: Hydrofuorocarbons (HFCs), Perfluorocarbons (PFCs), Sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) and Nitrogen trifluoride (NF3). F-gas emissions can be thousands of times worse for climate change than CO2 emissions (see www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch2s2-10-2.html)
subdivisions.label: F-gas

nodes.description: These emissions occur from industries such as petrochemicals, solvents, fertilizers and cement.
nodes.title: Non-energy

subdivisions.description: Emissions from the non-energy use of fossil fuels include: fugtive emissions associated with the extraction of feedstock material, as well as from solvents.
subdivisions.label: Other

subdivisions.description: Emissions from the use of chemical products includes emissions from fertilisers, solvents and F-gases used for refrigeration and other industrial processes.
subdivisions.label: Chemical use

subdivisions.description: Carbon dioxide (CO2) process emissions from cement production, are mainly caused by the chemical conversion of limestone (CaCO3) to lime (CaO) in the production of clinker (a key ingredient of cement). For further information see: http://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/gp/bgp/3_1_Cement_Production.pdf
subdivisions.label: Cement kiln

subdivisions.description: Freight emissions are from the bulk transport of goods by truck, train, ship, or aircraft. These are a combination of emissions from the burning of fuels in engines and the emissions from production of the materials used to make vehicles.
subdivisions.label: Freight

subdivisions.description: Land-use change emissions occur when positive net changes occur to three different carbon sources/sinks: aboveground biomass, belowground biomass and soil carbon. See accompanying report for further details.
subdivisions.label: Land-use change

subdivisions.description: Carbon dioxide is the main gas contributing towards global warming.
subdivisions.label: CO2

subdivisions.description: Total emissions associated with Oil
subdivisions.label: Oil

subdivisions.description: Methane is produced in landfills from anaerobic microbial decomposition of organic matter in solid waste disposal sites (IPCC guidelines). These emissions are allocated according to shares of 'Solid waste disposal on land' and 'Other waste handling' in EDGAR v4.2FT2012.
subdivisions.label: Landfills

subdivisions.description: CH4 and N2O are produced from anaerobic decomposition of organic matter by bacteria in sewage facilities and from food processing and other industrial facilities during wastewater handling. N2O may also be released from wastewater handling and human waste' (IPCC guidelines). Emissions are allocated according to shares of 'Wastewater handling' in EDGAR v4.2FT2012.
subdivisions.label: Waste water

subdivisions.description: The IPCC guidelines define waste emissions as: 'Total emissions from solid waste disposal on land, wastewater, waste incineration and any other waste management activity.' Emissions are both CH4 and N2O.
subdivisions.label: Waste

subdivisions.description: Emissions associated with personal travel include travel for personal business, family, shopping, visiting friends, sport, entertainment and holiday categories. These are estimated from trends in developed countries as information on developing countries is scarce. For further details on allocation assumptions see supporting documentation of Bajzelj et al. 2013.
subdivisions.label: Personal Travel

subdivisions.description: Emissions associated with commuting include travel to work, within work and business and school and education. These are estimated from trends in developed countries as information on developing countries is scarce. For further details on allocation assumptions see supporting documentation of Bajzelj et al. 2013.
subdivisions.label: Commuting

subdivisions.description: Emissions associated with the food consumed by livestock.
subdivisions.label: Feedlots

subdivisions.description: Emissions associated with creating and maintaining pasture for livestock.
subdivisions.label: Pasture

subdivisions.description: Emissions produced by Livestock (via enteric fermentation and manure)
subdivisions.label: Livestock

subdivisions.description: Emissions from settlements are estimated by allocating all emissions related to land 'clearing for settlements'.
subdivisions.label: Settlements

subdivisions.description: Emissions from food are a combination of many different sources. The majority are from the land-use and agriculture emissions required in food production. Other sources of emissions include: industrial food processing, emissions from the production of materials such as aluminium and chemicals used in the food supply chain, and emissions from residential and commercial appliances (e.g. refrigerators, ovens etc.).
subdivisions.label: Food

nodes.description: Methane emissions are 25 times worse for climate change than CO2 emissions (AR4 100-yr GWP)
nodes.title: CH4

subdivisions.description: Methane emissions are 25 times worse for climate change than CO2 emissions (AR4 100-yr GWP)
subdivisions.label: CH4

subdivisions.description: Emissions from the direct combustion of Coal and Peat products
subdivisions.label: Coal/peat

subdivisions.description: The production of steel is one of the largest sources of CO2 emissions in the industrial sector. The three main process routes are: Blast furnace/basic oxygen furnace, electric arc furnace or direct reduced iron.
subdivisions.label: Iron & steel

subdivisions.description: Total chemical and petrochemical production emissions are a combination of process emissions and direct emissions from fuel combustion. This sector was the largest industrial user of energy in 2014 (IEA 2017 ETP).
subdivisions.label: Chemical

subdivisions.description: Total cement production emissions are a combination of process emissions from the production of clinker and direct emissions from fuel combustion. The largest producer of cement is China accounting for 49% of world production in 2007 (IEA 2010 ETP).
subdivisions.label: Cement

subdivisions.description: Non-ferrous metal industry includes Aluminium production.
subdivisions.label: Non-ferrous

subdivisions.description: Food processing emissions are due to industrial cooking, washing and other activities associated with the industrial preparation of food.
subdivisions.label: Food processing

subdivisions.description: Production of paper products has increased by 23% since 2000 (FAO 2016) even though demand for printing paper is decreasing. This is due to growth in production of household and sanitary paper products (IEA 2017 ETP).
subdivisions.label: Paper

subdivisions.description: Emissions from the textile industry are predominantly caused by the energy needed to heat air and water in laundering. Other emissions arise from the cultivation and harvest of fibre crops (cotton etc.). For further information see: https://www.ifm.eng.cam.ac.uk/insights/sustainability/well-dressed/
subdivisions.label: Textiles

subdivisions.description: All other industrial sectors not mentioned above
subdivisions.label: Other

subdivisions.description: Industrial processes such as conveyor belts
subdivisions.label: Driven system

subdivisions.description: These include electronic appliances such as televisions, radios, personal computers or game consoles.
subdivisions.label: Electronics

subdivisions.description: This is the sum of the emissions required to produce Electricity and Industrial Heat by burning fossil fuels and Electricity producers' own use.
subdivisions.label: Utilities

subdivisions.description: Very high temperature industrial processes were fuels are combusted directly, examples include blast furnaces and cement kilns.
subdivisions.label: Fired system

subdivisions.description: High temperature industrial processes where fuels are combusted in boilers and steam or water are used as the heat transfer fluid.
subdivisions.label: Steam system

subdivisions.description: Other land emissions are the due to waste disposal and agriculture emissions.
subdivisions.label: Agriculture and Waste

subdivisions.description: Land use change emissions assocaited with the production of biomass for energy purposes
subdivisions.label: Biomass

subdivisions.description: Total emissions associated with Coal and  Peat
subdivisions.label: Coal/peat

subdivisions.description: Emissions associated with Vegetal agriculture are estimated by allocating all emissions associated with food crops/cropland. See supplementary information by Bajzelj et al. 2013 for further information.
subdivisions.label: Vegetal

subdivisions.description: Emissions associated with Meat/Dairy agriculture are estimated by allocating all emissions associated with livestock, pasture and feedlots. See supplementary information by Bajzelj et al. 2013 for further information.
subdivisions.label: Meat/Dairy/Fish

subdivisions.description: The IPCC defines fugitive emissions as 'an intentional or unintentional release of gases from anthropogenic activities excluding the combustion of fuels'. These emissions occur in the production, transformation and transport of fossil fuels. See accompanying report for further details.
subdivisions.label: Fugitive

subdivisions.description: Emissions associated with the production of fuels (excluding fugitive) from extraction to refining and conversion to final energy sources.
subdivisions.label: Own use

subdivisions.description: Emissions associated with communication are from some electronics used in residential and commerical buildings as well as materials such as paper. See supplimentary information for more details.
subdivisions.label: Communication

subdivisions.description: Passenger transport accounted for 63% of global road transport in 2014. See accompanying report for further details.
subdivisions.label: Passenger

subdivisions.description: Freight transport accounted for 37% of global road transport in 2014. See accompanying report for further details.
subdivisions.label: Freight

subdivisions.description: Emissions from clearing occur due to net changes in long term carbon sinks such as above and belowground biomass and the drainage of organic soils. These emissions are estimated using satellite data from the Harmonized World Soil Database, see accompanying report for further details.
subdivisions.label: Clearing for settlements

subdivisions.description: Emissions from clearing occur due to net changes in long term carbon sinks such as above and belowground biomass and the drainage of organic soils. These emissions are estimated using satellite data from the Harmonized World Soil Database, see accompanying report for further details.
subdivisions.label: Clearing for agriculture

subdivisions.description: The emissions are considered a net source if deforestation and destruction of forests is larger than forest growth. For further details, see accompanying report.
subdivisions.label: Clearing for biomass energy

subdivisions.description: The emissions are considered a net source if deforestation and destruction of forests is larger than forest growth. For further details, see accompanying report.
subdivisions.label: Logging

subdivisions.description: Adding nitrogen based fertilizers to agricultural soils produces N2O emissions due to nitrification and denitrification by microbes in soils.
subdivisions.label: Fertiliser use

subdivisions.description: The IPCC guidelines state: 'The anaerobic decomposition of organic material in flooded rice fields produces methane, which escapes to the atmosphere by ebullition (bubbling up) through the water column, diffusion across the water/air interface, and transport through the rice plants.'
subdivisions.label: Rice paddies

subdivisions.description: Emissions associated with manure occur due to large-scale farming of animals when manure is stored in low oxygen conditions and involve both methane and nitrous oxide.
subdivisions.label: Manure

subdivisions.description: Enteric fermentation occurs in animals when carbohydrates are digested and produces methane. Anthropogenic emissions occur from the cultivation of livestock. For further details, see accompanying report.
subdivisions.label: Enteric fermentation

subdivisions.description: Spark ignition engine
subdivisions.label: Petrol engine

subdivisions.description: Compression ignition engine
subdivisions.label: Diesel engine

subdivisions.description: Jet engine
subdivisions.label: Aircraft engine

subdivisions.description: These include LNG engines, steam engines and other sources of mechanical power
subdivisions.label: Other engine

subdivisions.description: Thermal comfort emissions are caused by heating and cooling of buildings. Allocations from residential energy use are based on several literature estimates of residential energy consumption: Zhou et al. (2007) 'Energy Use in China', IEA (2004) '30 years of energy use in IEA countries' fig. 5-2 and EIA (2012) 'Annual Energy Outlook 2012', p140,142
subdivisions.label: Thermal comfort

subdivisions.description: Emissions from the textile industry are predominantly caused by the energy needed to heat air and water in laundering. Other emissions arise from the cultivation and harvest of fibre crops (cotton etc.). For further information see: https://www.ifm.eng.cam.ac.uk/insights/sustainability/well-dressed/
subdivisions.label: Textiles

subdivisions.description: Emissions from the direct combustion of Oil
subdivisions.label: Oil

subdivisions.description: The emissions are considered a net source if deforestation and destruction of forests is larger than forest growth. For further details, see accompanying report.
subdivisions.label: Logging

subdivisions.description: Emissions associated with human settlements. This includes land use change emissions associated with clearing for settlements.
subdivisions.label: Settlements

subdivisions.description: The IPCC guidelines define waste emissions as: 'Total emissions from solid waste disposal on land, wastewater, waste incineration and any other waste management activity.' Emissions are both CH4 and N2O.
subdivisions.label: Waste

subdivisions.description: The IPCC guidelines define waste emissions as: 'Total emissions from solid waste disposal on land, wastewater, waste incineration and any other waste management activity.' Emissions are both CH4 and N2O.
subdivisions.label: Waste

subdivisions.description: Total emissions associated with Natural Gas
subdivisions.label: Natural gas

nodes.description: Nitrous oxide emissions are 298 times worse for climate change than CO2 emissions (AR4 100-yr GWP)
nodes.title: N2O

subdivisions.description: Nitrous oxide emissions are 298 times worse for climate change than CO2 emissions (AR4 100-yr GWP)
subdivisions.label: N2O

subdivisions.description: Crops destined for human consumption.
subdivisions.label: Food crops

subdivisions.description: Fibre crops are crops such as cotton that are not destined for feeding. For further information on allocation assumptions see Bajzelj et al. 2013 SI
subdivisions.label: Fibre crops

subdivisions.description: Emissions from the direct combustion of Natural Gas
subdivisions.label: Natural gas

subdivisions.description: Buildings and infrastructure have associated emissions due to the materials such as concrete and steel needed in their construction.
subdivisions.label: Buildings/infrastructure
